{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3166769,"name":"Henry","username":"townhen","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/6de8d8/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-17T14:10:57.416Z","cooked":"

Hey all, i am having trouble tuning my position-based closed-control loop for my sparkmax. The motor goes towards the position i give it but keeps going past it and doesn’t slow down/stop. Does anyone have any robotpy example code for positional PID besides the rev example project on github? i am using setReference() to set the position, and I have been playing with the FF, d, i, and other values within my code

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2023-03-17T14:10:57.416Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":78,"readers_count":77,"score":85.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":430626,"topic_slug":"need-help-with-position-based-pid","display_username":"Henry","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/need-help-with-position-based-pid/430626/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3166829,"name":"NewtonCrosby","username":"NewtonCrosby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-17T15:57:11.378Z","cooked":"

I don’t have any python code to help you, but I will tell you that generally when the PID drives the motor the way you think it’s going but never slows down or stops it’s almost always a case where your motor and your sensor are out of phase with each other.

To clarify, say you were using an encoder on a drivetrain:
For the sensor to be in phase with the motor, you need a positive input to your motor to increase your encoder count, and conversely, a negative input to your motor needs to decrease your encoder count.

If they are out of phase with each other, they can diverge to infinity. For your PID to be successful, the first calculation of your error against the setup needs to produce a motor output that will make the error decrease. As your PID loop continues execution, your scheduled loop should see your error converge to 0 when it is correct.

Same general comment as NewtonCrosby. I would output your desired position and current position and see what’s going on. The difference is the error and it better be getting driven to a small value.
